text:
President Volodymyr Zelenskyy 
travels to Washington today

as Congress weighs whether to 
approve more aid for Ukraine.

And the Senate has confirmed a new 
Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

Good morning. I'm Korva Coleman, from NPR 
News, and here are today's top stories:

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy is in 
Washington, D.C., today to meet with President

Biden. He's asking for sustained U.S. military 
aid to help Ukraine resist Russia's invasion.

NPR's Windsor Johnston tells us Zelenskyy will 
also visit congressional leaders on Capitol Hill:

"House Speaker Kevin McCarthy is expected to 
meet with Zelenskyy, but he has no plans to

provide the Ukrainian leader with a forum to make 
a direct appeal to lawmakers for additional aid.

"On the Senate side, Majority Leader Chuck Schumer 
has organized a meeting with the entire chamber.

"Speaking at the United Nations this week, 
Zelenskyy said, without continued support,
Russia will expand its fight within Ukraine."
NPR's Windsor Johnston reporting.

The Senate has voted overwhelmingly to confirm 
a new Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff:

Air Force General C.Q. Brown is the second 
Black officer to hold the post. As NPR's Greg

Myre reports, the Senate action circumvented 
a monthlong blockade by a Republican senator:

"In a distinguished career, General Brown 
has served as a combat pilot and as Chief

of the Air Force for the past three years. 
However, Alabama Republican Tommy Tuberville

blocked the confirmation of Brown and hundreds 
of other military officers who would normally

be approved in large batches. Tuberville objects 
to a Pentagon policy that helps military members

travel to receive abortion care if they face 
local restrictions. To get around Tuberville,

Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer brought 
Brown's nomination to a full Senate vote. He

was confirmed 83-11. Brown replaces General Mark 
Milley, who steps down at the end of the month.

The only other Black officer to be Chairman 
of the Joint Chiefs was General Colin Powell.
"Greg Myre, NPR News, Washington."

India has suspended visa services for 
Canadian citizens indefinitely. There

are escalating tensions over the murder of 
a Sikh leader in Canada. Sushmita Pathak

reports Canada claims India was involved in 
the killing, a charge that New Delhi rejects:

"The form that handles Indian visa applications 
in Canada said the service has been suspended due

to operational reasons. India has also issued an 
advisory for its citizens in Canada, especially

the large student population, urging them to 
remain vigilant as the diplomatic row worsens.

"Canada's government is investigating 
India's connection to the murder of a

separatist Sikh leader, Hardeep Singh Nijjar. 
India has strongly condemned the allegation.
"Both countries have expelled top diplomats.

"Calls for a Sikh nation-state separate from 
India have been growing among the large Sikh

diaspora in Canada. India considers its supporters 
terrorists and accuses Canada of sheltering them.
"For NPR News, I'm Sushmita Pathak in Delhi.
You're listening to NPR News.
